A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Klein Four-Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The Klein Four-Group is defined as a specific group consisting of certain permutations and is described as being isomorphic to the product of two cyclic groups of order 2. A group, by definition, must satisfy four fundamental properties: closure, identity, inverses, and associativity. The Associative Law, which states that the operation must satisfy $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c$, is one of these essential properties. Therefore, for the Klein Four-Group to be considered a group, it must inherently satisfy the Associative Law. Without the Associative Law being defined and satisfied, the structure described would not fulfill the definition of a group, and thus the concept of the Klein Four-Group would not make complete sense as a group. Hence, the Associative Law needs to be defined and understood for the definition of the Klein Four-Group to be valid and meaningful as a group.
